text: But we don’t know what we’re looking at yet. In front of is just a greyish-white flurry with nothing to orient us no sound except the whistle of a strong wind at a high altitude. We won’t know where we are until-- --a rocket flies right in front of us--right to left--and disappears from the frame as fast as it came into it. But probably saw it long enough to know it wasn’t a rocket, i was a world-class skier and we were standing five feet aw as she scorched the last few seconds of her run.
A survey was taken a few years ago that asked 300 professionals one question:

“What’s the worst thing that can happen in sports?” We're at the bottom of the slope now where the skier we j saw finished her run with a swoosh, and a hundred or so spectators gave her a round. The skier snapped out of her skis, picked them up, pushed up her goggles and looked ba up the slope toward the judges...
Some people answered losing a Game 7 and other people said getting swept in 4. Some people said--

--it was missing the World Cup and some Brazilians said it was losing to Argentina. Not just in the World Cup--anytime, ever, in any contest. We can see the whole slope now. This is a true story but except for my own I’ve changed all the names and I’ve done my best to obscure identities for reasons that’1l become clear. I’m Molly Bloom and right now I’m ranked 3rd in North America in Women’s Moguls.
The skier who just started has raced through the first se moguls, hits the ramp, which sends her up into mid-air wh she executes a trick and lands back on the course and hit the second set of moguls.
I have a BA in Political Science from the University of Colorado where I graduated Summa Cum Laude with a 3.9 GPA.

The skier’s made her way through the second set of backbreaking moguls and hits the second ramp, which sends into the air. We watch the judges examine her trick with expert eyes and then tap the keys on their laptops.
I got a 173 on the L-SATs. The median L-SAT score at Harvard Law School is 169.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 3.
This one’s much friendlier and families are skiing togeth in the sun with the Rocky Mountains as a backdrop. A COAC working with a 12-YEAR-OLD BOY, showing him the right mechanics for his push-off.

I was raised in Loveland, Colorado, about an hour outside Denver or four hours if it’s snowing. On a weekend family ski trip when I was 5 I was spotted by a coach. The COACH stopped paying attention to the 12-YEAR-OLD BOY became captivated by the sight of a 5-YEAR-OLD GIRL--a prodigy--who’s just exploded into his field of vision. Th COACH watches and then glances back up the slope where th girl’s FATHER is standing and watching.
(shouting) Attack it, Molly! Attack it! The COACH watches as the 5-YEAR-OLD GIRL hits the mini-mo section of the run.
I'd spend the next 18 years chasing winter and being coached by the best in the world.
Runners are competing in a road race and the front of the pack comes toward us as well-wishers cheer and hand out c of water along the sides.

I also ran pretty well. A 12-YEAR OLD GIRL appears among the runners--both the fi kid and the first female we’ve seen. She’s running alongs her FATHER and you can tell just by looking at her stride that this is an athlete.
I was running in a charity 5K when my back exploded.
(to her FATHER) Something’s wrong.
Tough it out. The 12-YEAR-OLD GIRL gives her father a quick “thanks” gl that her father doesn’t see before she pulls out several strides ahead of him and the rest of the men around her.
The 12-YEAR OLD-GIRL is being prepped for surgery.
I had what’s called rapid onset scoliosis.
An x-ray of a terribly curved spine.
My spine was curved at 63 degrees and I’d need a 7-hour surgical procedure that involved--
An x-ray of the same spine now fused with steel rods.
--straightening my spine, extracting bone from my hip, fusing eleven vertebrae together and fastening steel rods to the fused segments.
The 12-YEAR-OLD GIRL is in a hospital bed, post-op. From POV we can barely make out what a DOCTOR is saying to her FATHER and MOTHER.

She’s gonna be fine, but I wouldn’t let her ski anymore. Definitely not moguls and skiing competitively is out of the question. The FATHER is quietly devastated and slumps down on the closest surface while the DOCTOR and the MOTHER assure hi that “...she’s gonna be fine, she just won’t ski”, etc. W stay on the 12-YEAR-OLD GIRL’s eyes--she’s clocked her father’s reaction and even through her post-op morphine h her eyes are fighting back. It’s the last round of qualifying for the Salt Lake City Olympics. This is the Champion Run at Deer Valley. We can see that visibility is terrible, with snow coming diagonally and the wind whistling ominously at this altit
The altitude’s 8100 feet and the pitch is 52 degrees which is the same as the sides of the Great Pyramids. MOLLY stomps on her feet to keep them warm and starts to loosen her shoulders and neck.

The wind’s 20-25 miles an hour blowing left to right. It’s 3-below zero at the top of the slope and with 17 skiers in front of me, it’s gonna be like trying to stick a landing on a frozen infinity pool. Kiki blew out of her line. Shannon was off-balance on her second landing.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 6. MOLLY nods that she understands.

--setting the table for me. MOLLY snaps her boots into her bindings and taps her skis check how they feel.
Number 56 up. 44 on deck.
Go get it, here we go. MOLLY snaps her goggles down as the Coach steps back. MOL all alone now at the top of the mountain, snow blowing ar her.

I can make the Olympic team right now. And if I have three perfect runs in Salt Lake--the best runs of my life--I can beat the Austrians and the Swiss and have a realistic shot at the podium. Then the law school of my choice and then a start-up. A foundation that seeds entrepreneurial women and also teaches young girls to ignore most of their current role models.
Competitor ready.

The first is that when visibility * is bad the way it is now, race officials jam pine boughs in the snow at the edge of the jump so the skiers have some foreground depth reference. The second is that the * tightness of your bindings is determined by what’s called a DIN setting. If you’re a beginner your DIN setting is probably 2 or 3. If you’re an experienced weekend skier it’s probably 7 or 8. Mine’s 15. My boots are basically welded to my skis. Right...so how does this happen?-- In semi-slow motion, MOLLY gets airborne for her second t and almost as soon as she does, her right ski comes off a falls to the ground. All sound except Molly’s voice goes out.

It happened because I hit a pine bough and I hit it so precisely * that it simply snapped the release on my bindings. Right in that moment I didn’t have time to calculate the odds of that happening because I was about to land pretty hard on my digitally remastered spinal cord which is being held together by spare parts * from an Erector Set. MOLLY crashes to the ice and snow with terrible impact. * We go back to FULL SPEED now with Molly’s other ski immediately snapping off and skidding away as MOLLY keeps sliding and flipping over. We're still without sound--just the occasional slap of he helmet on the packed snow. And then her helmet flies off before she breaks through--MOS--the wood and wire fence a into a group of gasping and shouting spectators. We watch the whole thing again full speed. And we watch o watch it--SPECTATORS, her COACH, the JUDGES, TELEVISION C and her FATHER... Sound kicks back in and we hear the gasping crowd along w radio crackle of the SKI PATROL and EMTs as they race to scene. Molly’s FATHER tries to get to her as fast as he c MOLLY’s on her back, unconscious, blood-soaked snow on he face.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 9.

None of this has anything to do with poker. I’m only mentioning it because I wanted to say to whoever answered that the worst thing that could happen in sports was 4th place at the Olympics--seriously, fuck you.

I think there’s good and bad. I think there's jealousy. A lot of people are out to get you. I don’t trust them. I don’t trust people. The frame freezes with the GIRL’s eyes looking off-screen her father.

After my wipeout at Deer Valley I decided to take a year off before law school. Law school’s hard and I couldn’t spend the first year thinking about a pine bough. None. They didn’t burn witches in Salem, it’s a myth, that’s not how they killed them.
How did they kill them?
They hanged them or drowned them. Sometimes they piled heavy stones on their chests until they crushed them.
You're Molly Bloom, right?
Yeah.
You don’t look like you do in the pictures.

None of us do. We hear the clacking of footsteps coming down the hall an CHARLIE JAFFEY comes into view. CHARLIE’s a nice-looking with a kind face--around the same age as Molly or a coupl years older. He’s dressed well but not flashy.
Molly?
Yes.
I’m Charlie Jaffey.
Thank you again for seeing me.
You've met my daughter Stella?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 29.
Yes.
(to Stella) Isabel’s gonna be here in 45 minutes to take you to school. Did you finish the math?
Yeah.
Civ?
Yeah.
Do you know it? Could you teach it to your class today? If I asked you about Roman law, could you tell me?
Yes.

‘Kay, keep reading. MOLLY clocked that. CHARLIE (CONT’D) (to Molly) There aren’t too many people here this early but we’ll have coffee soon. Come on back to my office. MOLLY follows CHARLIE down a hallway-- CHARLIE (CONT’D) First thing’s first, when was the last time you slept? (beat) Today’s Friday.

Tuesday morning at 5AM I was arrested by the FBI. I spent Tuesday at LA County Jail. I was assessed to be a minimal flight risk and my bail was set ata hundred-thousand dollars. My mother signed over her house. I was released Wednesday morning and ordered to appear in Federal Court in New York’s Southern District at 10AM today.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 30.
In here. They walk into-- INT. CHARLIE’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS It’s a beautiful corner office with jetliner views of the river.
I flew here Wednesday and met with five attorneys yesterday.
Why didn’t you hire any of them?
Three of them had already been taken.
Yeah, there were 31 people named in your indictment--it’s Black Friday for criminal lawyers. What about the other two?
One told me that money was his second favorite form of payment.
Uh-huh.
And the fifth was also taken but he recommended I call you.
Why?

I told him I wanted someone who'd worked in the prosecutor’s office. That didn’t narrow the field much but then I told him I needed someone who wasn’t even a little bit shady because I’ve had some experience with that and that’s when the list got short. I told him I needed someone very good because this is nuanced. And I was given one day to find an attorney. (MORE )
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)
(pause) Do you know about me?
(pause) I've been briefed a little by my daughter who knows a lot about your story because her mother’s a moron.
The tabloids.

I’ve read some of the tabloids and I read the indictment after I got your call last night and I bought your book. CHARLIE’s picked up a copy of Molly’s Game-- CHARLIE (CONT’D) I’m only up to page 81, but Molly? Did you commit a felony and then publish a memoir about it?

I haven’t run a game in over two years. Not to spoil the ending but that’s when the government raided my game and took all my money, assuming all of it was made illegally which it wasn’t. I’ve been living at my mother’s house in Keystone and I wrote the book so I could start paying debts. I just finished a press tour for the book and moved back to Los Angeles.
Just to nail down the timeline, you ran games in LA for roughly six years?
Yeah.
Without taking a rake.
Right.
Then you ran games in New York for roughly two years? 31.
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 32.
I took a rake the last six months.
Then your game got raided, the government took all your money ina civil forfeiture and you left town.
I went to live with my mother at her house in Colorado. That was two years ago.
And it was there that you wrote this book.
Yes.
The book was released three weeks ago, you did a press tour and moved back to LA.
Yes.
And that’s where you were arrested by the FBI.
Yes.
(pause) So...In the first 81 pages you name a bunch of names.
(beat) I’m sorry?
You gave up the names of some movie stars who played in your game. MOLLY takes a moment...this is obviously a sore spot for and she’d rather not talk about it.
(pause) Yeah.  33.
Isn’t that against some sort of poker code?
There’s no poker code and there’s no law against lack of discretion.
Wouldn’t it be great if there were, though?
Are you taking me on as a client?
My retainer’s $250,000, do you have
No, I don’t have anything.
What about sales of the book?

Including that one that you bought I’ve sold one copy, but there's a lot of interest from Hollywood in buying my life rights. I’ll find a way to pay you. Charlie, ask around about me, my word is good.
Not to the guys you named.
I didn’t have a--just ask around about me.

(laughing) Unfortunately the people I'd ask are goin’ away for a while. What happened Tuesday morning was called a GPS Takedown. 31 people were arrested in the same instant. Someone you thought was a friend called you on your phone to make sure it was the one you were still using and when you answered that call, they had you painted and kept track of your movements until the agreed upon time. (MORE )
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 34.

Something in excess of 600 agents were dispatched to locations in New York and LA in coordinated strikes with automatic weapons and you’re trying to tell me you’re in my office because you raked a game of Texas Hold ‘Em?!
Yes!

Have you seen the other names on this indictment? Helly Habib, Mike Druzhinsky, Mike Anikovich, the Gershen Brothers? How deep were you into the Russian mob, Molly?! ‘Cause so far your tell-all doesn’t say. MOLLY’s well past tired and Charlie’s quick cross-examina has either taken something out of her or put something ba in. She stands up and walks to the window...
(pause) Why are you making your daughter read The Crucible?
So she can see what happens when a group of bored teenage girls gossip.
I’ve never read the play.
Many consider it to be the best play of the 20th Century.
Is that what many consider it to be?
I don’t defend violent criminals.
I’ve never hurt anyone in my life.
Your friends have.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 35.
I’ve never heard of 90 percent of the names in the indictment.
And the other 10 percent?
I didn’t know they were mobsters, I had no idea who they really were.

(pause) Let me ask you something. Reardon-- in the book--he didn’t say “Poor people bagels,” did he. (beat) I think I know who he is, I think I know a real estate lawyer who worked with him and quit. He called them “nigger bagels,” right?
(pause) I’m not telling you his name, he’s not involved in this.
But you were willing to name the movie stars.
None of that matters. Why is the FBI arresting me two years after--
Were you paid extra in your book deal to name the movie stars?
(pause) Yes.
I’m not your guy, Molly. I wish you good luck but this just isn’t for me. MOLLY hears that but still doesn’t leave...
(pause) Why did you leave the prosecutor's office and become a defense attorney?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 36.
My daughter.
You needed to make money.
That and I was usually one of the few people who knew where witnesses were being hidden.
It was dangerous.
Mm-hm. *
So you didn’t leave the * prosecutor’s office because you * wanted to stand up for the innocent and believe everyone’s entitled to the best defense?
Not really.

It would have been helpful if you were Spencer Tracy or--I didn’t know who the Russians were. (pause--calmer) I can get you the two-hundred and fifty-thousand, I left ten times that on the street, it’ll just take some time. ee OF

We do pro bono work--we regularly lend out our best litigators like me to the ACLU, Southern Poverty Law Center, veterans groups--but I * don’t think I can convince my partners to take a flyer on the Poker Princess.
I didn’t name myself the Poker Princess. CHARLIE picks up a copy of Us Weekly that’s been tabbed a reads--
“Molly Bloom, the self-proclaimed Poker Princess...”. *
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 37.

That's Us Weekly? I agree it would be unusual for them to print something that wasn’t true but it’s not true and if you think a princess could do what I did you’re incorrect. I’m getting that you don’t think much of me but what if every one of your ill-informed, unsophisticated opinions about me were wrong?
I'd be amazed.
Yeah you know what, bud? You would.
You don’t need me, you need a publicist.
No, I need a fuckin’ lawyer!
(pause) You never answered my question. When was the last time you slept?
(pause) It was a while ago.

(pause) I’m gonna walk you through the arraignment this morning, you shouldn’t do that alone. I’m gonna put some bodies on you and walk you through a side door. ‘Cause I don’t know what you’ve got on the Russians but neither do they and the Russians take care of shit, you understand what I’m saying?
Yes.

A SEVEN-YEAR-OLD GIRL is being pulled by a motor boat as tries to get up on one ski. She fails and falls hard into water.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 38. Her FATHER--the same father we’ve been seeing throughout- her MOTHER are on the boat and her FATHER shouts back--
Again! The SEVEN-YEAR OLD GIRL is tired but she gets herself rea to try again. The MOTHER isn’t happy about this but seems helpless and slightly cowed by the force of the FATHER.

My father’s a therapist and a psychology professor at Colorado State. The second rule of his house was that academic excellence and athletic excellence weren't optional and the first rule was that he made the rules. The GIRL is back on her water ski. The boat powers forwar again and the GIRL gets up on one ski for a moment before falls. The MOTHER, standing in the back of the boat as a spotter, raises a flag in the air to let nearby boats kno there’s a skier in the water.
You’re not getting out of the water till you do this. Again!
I was a skinny kid, and at 7 years old I didn’t have the core strength yet to pull this off. In October the water in Colorado is pretty cold and we'd been at this since 6AM.
(calling) Dad? I’m tired. The FATHER shakes his head...the MOTHER looks down, feeli for her daughter but not wanting to start a fight.
She’s tired. The FATHER whips the boat around and drives it up to the GIRL.
You're tired?
Yeah.
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 39.
What’s another word for tired? Name a synonym for tired and I’ll let you in the boat.
(pause) Weak.
That’s right. (holding out his hand) Get on in. The GIRL looks at her FATHER and his outstretched hand bu stays in the water...
Again.
INT. BARNEY’S/SHOE DEPARTMENT - DAY MOLLY’s wearing cut-offs, a sweatshirt and a Denver Bronc baseball cap as she looks at herself in a pair of Christi Loubitans.
I’ll take them.
Excellent.
Can you tell me what floor the dresses are on? INT. BARNEY’S/DRESS DEPARTMENT - A FEW MINUTES LATER
After three months of games I had enough money to buy some real clothes. A SALESWOMAN comes up to her--
Can I pull some styles for you?
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)
I’m looking for a dress that makes me look nothing like myself. The SALESWOMAN smiles...

Take off your hat, put your hair in a bun and put on your new shoes. I’1l pull some options. INT. BARNEY’S - A FEW MINUTES LATER 40. MOLLY comes out of the dressing room wearing a black dres that makes her look very sexy...
Well...where did that body come from? MOLLY stares at herself in the mirror...
I decided to postpone law school another year.
A game is underway and MOLLY has a whole new look.

I'd overheard stories about games that folded after one bad night and I needed this one to keep going and I needed to bring value to it. I knew if I wanted to cement my place there was one guy I needed to team up with and that was this man.
We see a HAND LIFTING CARDS, FINGERS PLAYING WITH CHIPS a then see that they belong to PLAYER xX.

The game had regulars and the game had guests and four of the regulars were famous actors and I’m going to call one of them Player X. Player xX subscribed to the belief that money won was twice as good as money earned. He lived to beat people and take their money. Here’s Player X talking one of the guests into folding the winning hand.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 4l. PLAYER X is in a showdown with the GUEST, who’s sweating whether to call or fold. The GUEST The GUEST
I swear on my--look at me--I swear on my mother’s life--I have you.

Player X was the best player at the table and tonight this guy was the worst. He’s staring at his cards-- even a reasonably good amateur would know it was mathematically the best hand, which in poker is called the nuts. There was forty- seven thousand dollars in the pot and the guest was holding the nuts but he was starting to get confused because a movie star was talking to him.
My mother’s life man, I’m not messing with you. thinks...surveys the cards...
(pause) Why would you be telling me?

Either I am messing with you OR you’re new to the game, you’ve had bad cards all night, you should’ve folded after the flop and I don’t want to win more of your money this way. I’ve got queens under here. Take your time. takes another moment...then tosses in his cards.
Fold. PLAYER X picks up his two losing hole cards--neither a qu and shows them to the guest--
Fuck you! The others cheer and pound the table as PLAYER X hauls in chips and the guest tries to put on a “just one of the gu face.”  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 42.

A fish is a particular kind of player. A fish has money. A fish plays loose and doesn’t fold a lot. A fish is good but not too good. PLAYER X looks over to MOLLY...MOLLY looks back and gives a half-smile. Chips get put down as a new hand is dealt.

The Viper Room may have belonged to Reardon but the game belonged to Player X. People wanted to say they played with him the same way they wanted to say they rode on Air Force One. My job security was gonna depend on bringing him his fish. But where would I find people with a lot of money who didn’t know how to spend it and liked to be around celebrities?
The club where Molly used to work. MOLLY’s talking to fou the CLUB GIRLS who drink shots for a living as the place pulses around them.

If they say they’re interested in poker you give them my number. I vet them. If they end up playing in the game I’ll give you a thousand dollars the first time they play and five-hundred every time after that. (handing one of them a slip of paper) Be sure to mention that these guys are all regulars. One of the club girls looks at the list of names...
Is this true? MOLLY hands her a wad of cash as we
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 43.
It’s a sad, seedy casino and we’re in an area where an eclectic collection of guys are playing Texas Hold ‘Em. MOLLY’s standing near a pit boss and watching one of the players. ee OK
The Commerce Casino is off the 5 freeway in East LA and no one’s ever going to confuse it with the French Riviera. I’d watch the tables for a while before I approached a friendly-looking pit boss.
The third chair at Table 8 can’t lose.
Unless there are players at his table who can win.
You know about the game at the Viper Room, right? *
Sure.
It’s a 10K buy-in, blinds are fifty and a hundred. A thousand for every player you send me. You get a piece of what they lose. No pros. I’m Molly.
DIEGO cuts the seal on a new deck and shuffles. *

Poker was my Trojan horse into the highest levels of finance, technology, politics, art, entertainment--all I had to do was listen. SERIES OF SHOTS--Different games on different nights as M listens to conversations between players and Googles vari things she hears.
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)
The art world is controlled by a few major dealers. Gagosian, Zwirner, and a couple more.
China’s telecom companies want to partner with other providers.
They alone control the market. They choose the artists they want to be important.
Obama’s gonna run.
They set the prices, they mark ‘em up 70, 80, 90 percent.
The owners don’t mind paying thirty- million dollars to an outfielder who hits 320 with 110 RBI’s, they mind paying ten-million dollars for a pitcher who was 8 and 14 last season.
90 percent mark-up. It’s unregulated money, usually all cash and unreported.
He’s the head of Google ventures and he says they’re working on a secret project to live forever.
To do what?
Live forever.
Are they close?
No. Call and raise.
His days are numbered.
His days are numbered.
I don’t know how much longer she’s gonna be in that job.
They’re very excited about a company called Twitter.
He’s done.
She’s gone.
I’m all in.

People have asked me what my goal was at that point, what was my endgame. Back then I would have laughed at that question. I was raised to be a champion, my goal was to win. At what and against whom? Those were just details.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 46. We’re on MOLLY’s face as a player, off-screen, says what Molly’s thinking...
All in.
MOLLY looks over the modest but nice new place with a ren agent.
I had my own apartment now--
MOLLY gets out of a brand new Audi with a bag of bagels--
--a new car and seventeen-thousand dollars in a shoebox.
MOLLY’s standing alone in a crowd drinking a glass of * champagne.

One night a friend asked me to come with her to a pre-Oscar party being hosted by the head of one of the bigger talent agencies. Nothing’1l remind you that you don’t belong * quite as fast as a party where you don’t belong. And I must’ve been invisible because two four-thousand dollar suits were talking business right next to me.
He’s never gonna agree to that number.
He’s already agreed to it. *
You know that? *
Rich played cards with him.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 47.
When?
Tuesday night at the game. *
The Lakers game? *
Cards. Poker. The poker game. *
I don’t know what you’re talking * about. *
Oh, man, you have to know about the * game. It’s exclusive, you need an * invitation, the winners are coming * home with a hundred thousand dollars and the losers keep coming back.
Where do they play?
No one knows where. Nobody who plays talks about it and everybody wants in. But my point is that Rich played with him and he’s agreeing to the number.
And just like that, I was about to belong.
I need to get a seat at this game. * MOLLY downs what’s left of her champagne and steps to the agents--
Excuse me, I couldn’t help overhearing you. (beat) I’m Molly Bloom and I run the game you were talking about. If you give me your cards I can get in touch if a seat opens.
(pause) Seriously?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 48.
The game’s real?
Who plays?
You can just give me your cards. * They hand her their cards.
I'll be in touch. MOLLY walks away and we stay on her face as she glides * through the party and we see a small smile as we --

Press and paparazzi are on the steps behind police barricades. No one notices a black SUV has driven past th and pulls up to the side of the courthouse. A BODYGUARD hops out the front passenger side and opens t back door for another BODYGUARD who helps Molly out of th car. The three of them head for a side entrance as we --
CHARLIE is standing and waiting as MOLLY and the bodyguar come in and walk through a metal detector. They all make their way down the hall--

Here’s all that’s gonna happen today. The judge is gonna ask each defendant if they’ve read the indictment or if they’d like the court to read it to them. Then the judge is going to ask you how you plead and you’ll answer, “Not Guilty.” I’ll make it clear for the record that I’m not your counsel but that I’m appearing on your behalf at the arraignment. In propria persona.
“In propria persona” means on your behalf.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 49.
Yeah.
No, I’m saying it means on your behalf.
I am appearing on your behalf.
“In propria persona” means that you’re appearing on your behalf, not my behalf.

(beat) I’ll check that out but the point is I’m not your lawyer and I’1l make that clear for the record. He stops her before they walk into the courtroom and show little compassion... CHARLIE (CONT’D) Look...my office’ll give you a list of names when we’re done. There are plenty of firms that’ll just be happy for the exposure. You'll be fine.
I appreciate it.
(pause) Alright. It’s a scary room. Don’t be scared.
Charlie, I know what’s what, okay? CHARLIE opens the courtroom door and holds it for MOLLY a the TWO BODYGUARDS as they walk into--

The courtroom is huge and ornate and right now it’s a bit a spectacle. On the right side of the gallery are the defendants and t lawyers--about 60 people in all. Behind a plexiglass partition are some more defendants in prison coveralls an shackles. The defendants range in age from early-20’s to 80's.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 50. On the left side of the gallery are the wives and girlfri of the defendants. They’re all beautifully dressed and manicured and have on some of their gaudiest jewelry for occasion. Seated in back of them are the press and it was a tough ticket to get. At the prosecutor’s table are three Assistant U.S. Attorn including HARRISON WELLSTONE, the lead attorney on the ca who we’ll get to know later. JUDGE DUSTIN FOXMAN is already seated at the bench and is quietly going over some business with the prosecutors as packed courtroom hums with quiet chatter. CHARLIE points a bodyguard to where he wants Molly to sit four taped off seats on the right side toward the back. A MOLLY and the BODYGUARDS take their seats, CHARLIE stands the aisle a moment and looks at HARRISON, the lead prosecutor. HARRISON turns back from the bench and heads his table and sees Charlie. HARRISON half-smiles and give CHARLIE a small wave. CHARLIE gives him a small wave back takes his seat on the aisle next to one of the bodyguards MOLLY’s clocked all that.
(quietly to MOLLY) You got a good judge, he’s a good guy.
How ‘bout the prosecutor? CHARLIE takes a moment and then shakes his head “no”. JUDGE FOXMAN raps his gavel once, the room quiets down, a everyone takes their seats.
Counsel, please state your appearances for the record?
Good morning, Your Honor, Harrison Wellstone and Jack Brennan on behalf of the Government, joined at counsel table by FBI Agent Deborah D’Angelo.
Are there any oral motions at this time?
He OK  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 51. One of the defense lawyers stands up--
Your Honor-- The seemingly routine business of the hearing continues u the following--

(quietly to the bodyguard) Switch with me a second. CHARLIE and the BODYGUARD switch places so that Charlie’s sitting next to Molly now. CHARLIE (CONT’D) (quietly) Do you know what a “Vor v Zakone” is? A “Vor"?
The literal translation is “thief- in-law.” It’s the Russian equivalent of a Don or a Godfather. Nikolai Illyanovich is a Vor. He's the one who tried to fix the Salt Lake City Olympics.
I wasn’t there.
He’s also had a lot of people killed. It’s basically do what I’m telling you or we’ll kill your kids.
I've never had an audience with the Vor, I’m not a made man and I don’t know who Nikolai Illyanovich is.

(pointing to a man behind the plexiglass) He’s standing right there. I can introduce you guys, you’re co- defendants. (to the BODYGUARD) Switch back.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 52. CHARLIE and the BODYGUARD switch back to their original seats. The business of the court continues.
Defendant 4, Jonathan Hirsch.
Good morning, Your Honor. David Siegel for the purposes of today’s appearance.
Has the defendant seen a copy of the indictment?
Yes, Your Honor.
Have you discussed it with your lawyer?
I have.
Do you waive its public reading?
Yes.
How do you plead at this time?
Not Guilty.
Thank you, you may be seated.
Defendant 5, Arthur Azen. The court’s business continues as--
(whispering to the

Switch with me. CHARLIE and the BODYGUARD switch seats again and CHARLIE speaks quietly to MOLLY--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 53. CHARLIE (CONT’D) Just in case your lawyer doesn’t mention it, the next time you appear in front of the judge you should re-think your clothes. You look like the Cinemax version of yourself.
I sold my clothes after the government seized all my money two years ago which incidentally was the last time I ran a poker game but I think I mentioned that already.
(beat) Okay. (pause--then quietly) Your old boss--the one you call Reardon--he was kind of a jerk to you. Why would you cover for him by changing it to “poor people bagels”? ee OK
(quietly) I promise it couldn’t matter less.
(shrugs) * Just making conversation. *
CHARLIE’s not really satisfied but he taps the bodyguard they switch back.
Do you waive its public reading?
I do.
How do you plead at this time?
Not guilty.
Defendant 7, Molly Bloom. MOLLY and CHARLIE stand and when they do, everyone in the courtroom turns around to get a look at the Poker Princes  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)
Good morning, Your Honor. Charles Jaffey, just for the purposes-- And CHARLIE stops mid-sentence and thinks...
(pause) It’s good to see you, Mr. Jaffey, are you with us this morning? (beat) Mr. Jaffey?
Just a moment please, sir. (to the BODYGUARD) Switch back. They switch--
Seriously?
You said you left ten-times that much on the street. Back at my office. I said it’s a $250,000 retainer and you said you left ten times that on the street.
Yeah.
Counsel, I need to record your appearance.
Please the Court Your Honor, just one moment. (to Molly) You were extending credit. You’re destitute and you left two anda half million dollars on the street?
I had to.
Didn’t anyone try to buy your debt sheet?
Everyone tried to buy my debt sheet, is this the right time to-- 54.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)
Why didn’t you sell it like you sold your clothes?
I couldn't.
Why?
I couldn’t be sure how they were gonna collect.
(pause) I was afraid you were gonna say that.
Counsel? CHARLIE thinks...
(pause) Charles Jaffey for the defendant, Your Honor.
For the purposes of this hearing only?

No sir, I’m Molly Bloom’s attorney. She’s read the indictment, discussed it with her lawyer, waives her right to have it read to her and pleads “Not Guilty”. HARRISON clocks this, smiles and shakes his head.
Defendant 8, Alexander Gollib.
Thank you.
I'll need to keep reading your book.
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 56.

I have two younger brothers who were also overachievers. While I was ranked 3rd in North America, my brother Jeremy was Number 1 in the world.

text: And while I was placing into A.P. Chemistry as a junior, my brother Jordan was doing it when he was 12- years-old or something, I don’t know. MOLLY’S CHILDHOOD HOUSE - NIGHT Molly, now 15, is having dinner with her FATHER, MOTHER, two YOUNGER BROTHERS.
I was a hotshot student and a hotshot skier everywhere but my own house. And that’s where we live. As I got older I began to bait my father into fights without really knowing why I was doing it.
Let’s go around the table. Impress me with what you learned at school today. Jeremy Bloom.
The usual stuff.
Usual stuff. Jordan Bloom.
Usual stuff.
I am impressed. Molly?
I learned that Sigmund Freud was both a misogynist and an idiot and that anyone who relies on his theories of human psychology is a quack. The FATHER laughs a little and the MOTHER looks nervous.
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 58.
I don’t know why you'd say that.
You asked me what I learned in school today.
Is this Mrs. Linwood?
Yep.
Did she happen to mention anything about his work on the unconscious mind?

His dream analysis has the credibility of a horoscope but what got my attention was that he opposed the women’s emancipation movement. He believed that a woman's life is about their reproductive functions.
So you were really getting to the nuts and bolts of why middle-class, suburban white girls have been oppressed for centuries.
Mrs. Linwood--
Barbara Linwood doesn’t like men, Molly.
She doesn’t like dicks, Dad, there’s a difference. The FATHER looks at MOLLY then throws his fork down on hi plate with a frightening clang.
Molly, don’t say things like--
Don’t disrespect me like that at the table.
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 59.
I wasn’t disrespecting you, I was disrespecting Freud and it’s a kitchen table, it’s not the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.
And I’m a professional psychologist, not a quack.
I never said (you were a)--
(over) Yeah you did and don’t do it again and don’t ever use that language again.
Okay, ignore my teachers, watch my language and respect the kitchen table. What else do I need to do before I’m allowed to disagree with you?
Make your own money so you can live in your own house and eat your own food.
MOLLY counts out a big stack of hundreds.
I'd been running the game for 13 months and saved twenty-eight thousand dollars. REARDON counts two stacks of chips and throws them in the pot.
Call.
I was recruiting and vetting players, keeping the books, collecting and delivering checks--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 60.
Straight to the eight. PLAYER X won and REARDON lost.

--meeting the needs of all the players throughout the week and still working full-time for Reardon, who’d made it clear that if I quit the office job I’d lose the game. REARDON picks up what’s left of his chips--

I’m done. Reardon gets called “Pussy” and other names before the players go back to their own conversations and Reardon ma his way over to Molly. He puts his chips down in front of which Molly skillfully stacks, counts, and types into her spreadsheet as she says--
(quietly) I thought he had trips too. He was slow-playing into the river and he hid the pocket 3 pretty well. Tough beat. You owe the game--
I know what I owe the game, I want to talk to you a minute.
(beat) Okay.
Outside.
A band is loading out its equipment into a couple of wait vans. A back door opens and REARDON comes out, followed b MOLLY.
Is he cheating?
No.
How would you know?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 61.
I'd know.
He and Diego aren’t in bed together?
No.
What about him and you?

(beat) If you’re asking what I think you're asking, no. In fact there’s nothing you could be asking where it wouldn’t be no. A fifty-two card deck produces hundreds of millions of random patterns but every time one of you loses two weeks in a row you’re sure something fishy must be up.
I’m gonna stop paying you.
What do you mean?
As my assistant.
You're firing me?
I’m not firing you, I'm just gonna stop paying you. You get paid once a week from the game, it doesn’t seem fair.
But I also have a job working for you 24 hours a day.
And if you didn’t have that job you wouldn’t have the game, you understand what I’m saying?
(pause) I understand each of the words that you’re saying, but--  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)
Look--
24 hours a day every day. You’re gonna stop paying me to do that job because I’m making too much money doing my second job and if I say no I'll lose both jobs. Because it doesn’t seem fair?
Business is bad right now, welcome to the real world. MOLLY takes a moment and then goes for it--

Alright, here it is: Banks are loaning you money and they shouldn’t. You’re a bad risk, they know that. So the debt service on your loans is close to 20 percent which is crazy. 20 percent is barely survivable if it’s a bridge loan but, for instance, it’s taken you 10 years to build seven houses, all of which are worth less than they were before you built them because the housing market’s on a downward trajectory for the first time in the history of houses and that’s why business is bad, not because you pay me four-hundred and fifty dollars a week.
You're a business savant?
I've read every piece of paper in your office.
You’re making thousands in tips every week, why do you care about (four-hundred and fifty dollars a week?)
(over) I care about it because I don’t want to pick up your dry cleaning for free.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 63.

You don’t have bargaining power here. You can refuse the pay cut but you’ll lose the game. (handing her a few chips) Cash me out please. REARDON heads back inside and Molly stands there alone a moment...
There’s an old saying:
As a VALET opens Molly’s car door and MOLLY, looking fantastic in business clothes, steps out.

“Never wait until your ski releases before you check to see if a small pine bough’s in your way.” I don’t know how old that saying is but I wasn’t going to wait for Reardon to take the game away before I put a plan in place. MOLLY’s met by a HOTEL MANAGER.
The next morning I made appointments at the Four Seasons, the Peninsula and the Beverly Hills Hotel.
The MANAGER is showing MOLLY the expensive suite with beautiful views.
The suite was fifty-two hundred a night.
As DIEGO fits a Shuffle Master into the hole that’s been into the table.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 64.
I spent seventeen-thousand on a Shuffle Master that was installed in the table.
The view is even more spectacular and glamorous at night. Delicious food is being put on small tables between the s by an attractive server.
Food was brought in from Mr. Chow and available to eat on side tables. An equally attractive BARTENDER is preparing the bar.

There was Macallan 18, Belvedere, 1942, Remy Martin, and an ‘88 Lafite Rothschild served by a bartender who’d already memorized your drink. Cohibas and Monte Cristos were in the humidor and two licensed massage therapists were there to rub your shoulders as you played.
MOLLY’s having her hair blown out while working a spreads on her laptop. An outfit is being laid out on the bed.

A professional stylist turned me into what my defense attorney would later call the Cinemax version of myself. I spent almost everything I had in preparation for the phone call I new was coming. We HEAR a cell phone ring before we--
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 65.
MOLLY rolls over in bed and looks at the ringing cell pho It’s Reardon.
(into phone) Hello? REARDON doesn’t sound good.
I want you to listen to me. ‘Cause you need to hear this.
(pause) Are you alright?
Are you listening? You need to hear this.
Where are you?
I need to tell you something in plain English and I need to know that you understood it.
Okay.
You are unimportant, did you hear me? And you are fired. (pause) Did you hear me? The job, the game, you're fired.
Why don’t you lie down for a while.
You're fired, Molly.
Can I ask why?
You were supposed to set up the TV.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 66.
I did, I installed it myself.
I’m looking at a blank screen.
I told you yesterday your cable would be out until 10am today.
It was your responsibility.
I told you there would be cable outages in your area. It’ll be back on by 10am. I don’t have control over Comcast.
How many of my friends are you sleeping with?
I’m not sleeping with any of them.
That’s not what I heard.
Reardon, listen to me, with a hazmat suit I wouldn’t sleep with-- just lie down.
Can I give you some advice? Lose the bitchy air. Lose the superior air. Go to the office and get your stuff and be out of there before I show up. REARDON hangs up and we --
an attractive young woman, is putting the last of Molly’s things in a box when MOLLY walks into the office.
Hi. Are you Molly?
Yeah.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 67.
I’m Leah. Reardon asked me to pack your personals.
I appreciate it.
He also asked me to get the numbers of tonight’s players so I can confirm the list for tonight. I’m really sorry.
Don’t be. My phone’s in my car. I’ll text you all the numbers you need when I get downstairs.
MOLLY’s got her box of stuff from the office next to her the passenger seat as she pulls into the Four Seasons and met by the hotel manager.
I texted my replacement a bunch of random numbers with 310 area codes. Then I sent a text to the players for tonight and told them the game had been moved to the Four Seasons Hotel, Suite 1401.
The players are sitting and standing around, drinking champagne and cocktails, smoking a cigar, standing on the terrace, etc. The place looks beautiful and so does MOLLY
Fellas, can I have your attention a moment?
Where’s Reardon?
I'll be hosting a game in this suite every Tuesday night. If you play tonight you’ll be guaranteed a seat at the game for life. If you’d prefer to play at the Viper Room there'll be no hard feelings.
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 68. There’s quiet for a moment and everyone kind of looks at PLAYER X...PLAYER X looks at MOLLY and smiles, who looks at him...blank but confident. *
The game is in full swing and high spirits. MOLLY and her laptop are observing from a little distance.

The game was mine now. I incorporated and MDB Event Planning was born. I paid taxes and 1099'’d my employees. I never became romantically or sexually involved with any of the players. It just wouldn’t have been professional-- this was back when I was still making good decisions. And I went to a lawyer to make absolutely sure all this was legal. INT. LOUIS BUTTERMAN’S OFFICE - DAY * MOLLY sits across from LOUIS BUTTERMAN, a lawyer. *
Are you taking a rake?
No.
Then you’re not breaking the law * but can I give you some advice? *
Please. *
There’s a saying in my business. * Don’t break the law when you’re breaking the law.
What do you mean?
No drugs, no prostitutes, no muscle to collect debts.
I don’t do anything like that but you just said I wasn’t breaking the law.
Let’s keep it that way, ‘cause you don’t want to break the law when you’re breaking the law.
(beat) Am I breaking the law?
Not really.
We're able to find out for sure, aren’t we? Laws are written down.
You're not taking a percentage of the pot?
No
You’re running a square game.
A game is underway and it looks like everything Molly’s describing.

My game had a tricky ecosystem. It was built around escapism and exclusivity. These guys could buy their way into anything and anyone but here in this room you couldn’t buy your win. You couldn’t buy me, you couldn’t buy the girls and you couldn’t buy a seat at the table. There’s nothing as sweet as a win you have to work for and the wins and losses were compelling and they were real. Of course it helped that the players were gambling addicts.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)
The game has ended. Diego’s breaking down the table, the women are cleaning up and PLAYER X is talking to MOLLY.
I've had a thought.
Yeah?
Raise the stakes.
(pause) To what?
50K buy-in. Blinds are five-hundred and a thousand.
(pause) That’s uh...that’s a 500 percent hike.
Yeah.
I don’t think it’s a good idea.
(calling out) Could you give me the room a second? They wait for the women to leave the room...
The players who are losing a hundred-thousand a week are gonna be losing half a million.
And the players winning a hundred- thousand--

--will have no one left to play with. Players are gonna get hurt, others are gonna get killed and some of them are gonna drop out. It’s not sustainable and we’ll lose the game.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 71.
Find new players.
He meant find new fish and with these stakes that was gonna be challenging. First up was Donnie Silverman.

text: Donnie won the World Series of Poker last year and got in touch with me through one of the players. INT. MOLLY’S APARTMENT/LIVING ROOM - NIGHT MOLLY’s watching the World Series of Poker on her laptop. can see that DONNIE’s one of the players as MOLLY hits pa makes a note on a pad and then continues watching.

Ordinarily if you were at the final table at the World Series that would automatically disqualify you from playing in my game but a Vegas contact told me to look at the film. So that night I watched seven hours of the world’s worst spectator sport.

location: OUTSIDE THE HOME OF PLAYER X

text: MOLLY’s standing with a check for PLAYER X.
Are you fuckin’ nuts? Donnie Silverman won the World Series of Poker.

He took eleven hands at the final table. He had the nuts on eight of them and three of those--three-- were two-outers with four players still in the hand. He ran hot. He doesn’t lock his chips down, he’s reckless, gives tons of action and just won 12-million dollars.
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 72.
(beat) Okey-doke.

Player X said he met him at the Commerce Casino and that he'd be good for the game but I wasn’t seeing what he was seeing. He played tight, folding after the hole cards 64 percent of the time. HARLAN tosses his cards into the middle of the table.
It wasn’t clear where his money came from. He produced backyard wrestling videos and other low-rent productions--
--as HARLAN wins the hand and pulls in his chips.
--but worst of all, Harlan Eustice was a good card player. And Player X knew he was good but he wanted him anyway and he wanted him badly. You'll see why in a moment. a *

Two men in their 30’s, BRAD and NEAL, are walking on the beach toward the house and we move in on BRAD--

I'd been asked to throw together a game on a Saturday night at the Malibu house of a man who made his money by co-starring in a sex video opposite a woman who made her money by being born with it.

Well if you give me his information I’ll check him out. Ce ee a

“Derrick’s gonna vouch for him” meant Derrick would cover any losses if Brad didn’t pay. Up to any amount. DERRICK nods his head “yes” without taking his eyes off t table. MOLLY looks at BRAD again, then waves him over.
A game is underway and BRAD’s playing now.
But he could pay, and did. As we go through a SERIES OF CUTS showing BRAD betting hu stacks of chips, losing, buying in from MOLLY for another 50K, betting huge, losing, etc.

Bad Brad had raised 45-million dollars for a fund that traded oil futures and every week he came to the game, lost a quarter of a million dollars and tipped me 10- thousand so he could play the next week. He wasn’t getting any better and the guys were feasting on him. BRAD loses another hand and walks over to Molly’s table.
Can I get another fifty?
Hey, let’s talk for a second.
Sure.
Brad, this game may not be for you.
I know I’m no card shark.

These are your losses after ten weeks. And you’ve won...never. The strongest players have losing weeks and the weaker players get lucky but I’ve never seen someone not win, you know, ever. It’s actually a statistical anomaly.
Yeah I know. I like playing with the guys. I don’t have that many friends. Don’t take my seat away, I can tip you more.
No, your tips are very generous. How about if I got you some books to read? Or even a pro to give you lessons?
Sure. Maybe. Let me think about it.

Tell ‘em what’s smart this week.

I was in the owner’s box at Dodger Stadium when People Magazine's Sexiest Man Alive called me. I was dating the owners’ son at the time and the night before we’d had a discussion about priorities. INT. BOYFRIEND’S BEDROOM - NIGHT The BOYFRIEND’s in bed as MOLLY comes into the darkened r dressed for the poker game she’s just come from.
It’s 4:30 in the morning.
(quietly) Hey babe, I’m sorry to wake you up.
You didn’t wake me up, I’ve been waiting up.
You shouldn’t have, that’s why I have a key.
I don’t know any other guy who’d put up with his girlfriend staying out till 4:30. Dressing like that for millionaire movie stars, being the only woman in the room--
I’m sorry, I didn’t realize until just now that you’re mad.

When you’re not running a game you’re out recruiting, you sleep-- when you sleep--you have two phones clutched to your chest, you went out in the middle of the night last night, I don’t even know where--

You couldn’t pick up the check in the morning?
You can’t let a gambler sleep ona debt.
I don’t think this argument’s gonna get me anywhere.
You want to have sex like we’re strangers?
I want to make this work!

Okay. Okay. I do too. And tomorrow night I’m gonna come with you to the game and I’m not gonna make any calls or take any calls and I’m gonna make a good impression on your parents. I’m gonna be there just for you.
I over-promised. EXT. DODGER STADIUM/OWNER’S LUXURY BOX - NIGHT Back with MOLLY, her BOYFRIEND, the PARENTS and other gue some of whom are praying or covering their eyes, etc.
‘Cause the thing is if you’re sitting in the owner’s box with the owners, who are also your boyfriend’s parents-- We see hits of the scoreboard that demonstrate what Molly talking about.

--and your team is batting in the bottom of the ninth, down by a run, one out, runners on first and third and a win means you’re in the playoffs, you’re really not at that moment supposed to take a phone call. MOLLY’s phone buzzes and she sneaks a peak at the caller The BOYFRIEND clocks this.

I wanted this man in the game, and not because he was People’s Sexiest Man Alive. I already had three of them at the table. But this one was a heavyweight--one of the biggest stars in the world. A 9-time Grammy winner whose last two albums debuted at Number-1 on the Billboard chart. Smart, charismatic, and influential, he wasn’t a recluse but you didn’t see him at parties or clubs. He was powerful fish bait, he was whale bait, he was an actual rock star and he was good business. And if I had him as an ally I wouldn’t be dependant on Player xX. MOLLY makes her decision, takes out her phone, tells her BOYFRIEND she’s sorry and she’ll be just a second and get the reaction you’d expect.
I'll call him Player Y.
(into phone) This is Molly.
They come back from commercial with bumper music and animation. JENNY MCCARTHY is introducing their next guest with a giant copy of Molly’s Game projected on the rear screen.
eK eK

Molly Bloom was dubbed the Poker Princess for running underground high stakes poker games for Hollywood superstars, Wall Street big wigs--
The new book, Molly’s Game, just out today, is already making headlines with big stories in Vanity Fair and People Magazine.
Over a montage of seedy-nightlife-in-LA shots--
In the heart of Hollywood, hidden beneath the notorious Viper Room, a narrow hallway leads into a musty room, a poker table, and the secret life of Molly Bloom. We hear MOLLY’s voice off screen--
Not as secret as I'd hoped. We pull back and we’re in-- INT. CHARLIE’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS --as CHARLIE clicks off the TV. Molly’s standing in the doorway.
Hey. C’mon in. Throw your coat anywhere.
Thank you.
How was your flight?
Just fine.
How are you paying for plane tickets between LA and New York?  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)
I had two-million points left on my AmEx. They took away the card but they let me keep the points which I thought was nice of them.
It was. So you had meetings.
Hm?
You had meetings out in LA about the book?
I did.
With the studios.
Yes. And a few other people.
You have an agent working with you?
I do.
Was there interest?
A company that owns 400,000 video poker machines wants to put my face on them.
Anything else?
Treat Magazine made a generous offer.
Treat?
It’s a new magazine for the high- end photography enthusiast. 80.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 81.
They want you to pose naked.
I'd be the April treat.
I meant interest in the book.
Yes.
Any offers?
A few I guess. A couple. Seven.
Really.
Yes.
And...?
I passed.
You passed on seven offers.
You will be paid, Charlie.
No, I’m just curious why you passed on seven offers.
Creative differences. Should we start?

Okay, you see this? CHARLIE’s motioned to a stack of documents-- CHARLIE (CONT’D) This is discovery. Let’s see what we've discovered. CHARLIE will draw a crude diagram on a white board as he speaks.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 82. CHARLIE (CONT’D) Over here we have Michael Druzhinsky, Michael Anikovich and Michael Slobo. The three Mikes. CHARLIE draws three “M”s and puts a circle around it. * CHARLIE (CONT’D) The three Mikes run a chain of corrupt medical clinics and they’ve been committing insurance fraud, wire fraud and mail fraud on an epic scale. Over here is the Taiwanchik-Gershen Organization. * CHARLIE writes “TGO” and draws a circle around it. * CHARLIE (CONT’D) They’re a worldwide bookmaking operation handling hundreds of millions of dollars a year in illegal sports betting. And over here is the Habib-Gershen * Organization. * CHARLIE writes “HGO” and draws a circle around it. The th organizations are now in a triangle on the white board. CHARLIE (CONT’D) Also an illegal bookmaking operation but this one financed by an art gallery owned by Hillel Habib who everyone calls-- *
Helly. MOLLY and CHARLIE both understand that MOLLY just admitte knowing these guys.
(pause) This is the Russian mafia. And the three are tied together in the indictment through...? A poker game. CHARLIE writes “Molly” in the middle of the triangle and draws a circle around it.
Were they tapping my phone?
No.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy)
Thank God.
They were tapping the phones of everyone you talked to.
Okay.

Druzhinsky’s phone was tapped. They’ve got you confirming that you ran raked games at various locations in New York and they've also got a confidential informant confirming that you ran raked games at various locations in New York. You were in violation of 1955-- that’s the part of the U.S. Code that makes it illegal to run an illegal gambling business. (pause) You know what you did? You finished writing your book before the good part happened.
You get a kick outta yourself, don’t you. CHARLIE lifts up a copy of Molly’s Game--
I don’t like this picture.
Thank you.
You look like the cat who ate the canary and then told the canary’s parents about it.
I don’t like it either but it’s the picture the publisher wanted and I wasn’t given a vote.
I liked the book though. A good story well told.
Thank you. 83.  84.
I need you to tell it again. From the beginning and this time without leaving anything out. Would you like a glass of water?
I'd like a glass of bourbon.
And one more thing.
Yeah.
I need your hard drives.
Going back how far?
What do you mean?
I kept my hard drives when I'd buy a new laptop.
You’re kidding.
It had records of who owed what and spreadsheets on the players.
They have more than that. Every time you charge your phone by plugging it into your computer the computer records all your text messages and e-mails.
(pause) Are you joking?
I want to run a forensic imaging of your hard drives.
No, I’ll be destroying those hard drives.  85.
You can’t, they’re evidence.
I’m going to blow them up. I’m literally going to use explosives and then scatter the remains in the Colorado River.
You already told me they exist.
You’re just gonna have to pretend I didn’t tell you.
I can’t do that.
I don’t have any hard drives, I work with an abacus.
Molly--
There are no hard drives!
If you destroy evidence and obstruct justice on top of the charges already brought against you in this case, you will, I promise you, be incarcerated.
You don’t understand what’s in those text messages.
I understand that you’ve had boyfriends and that there are gonna be private exchanges.

You don’t understand. There are going to be those messages and they’1ll be embarrassing but there are also going to be messages that would destroy lives. Other lives. There are messages that would end careers and obliterate families. If the text messages were made public--
They won't be.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 86.
If they were--
They won't be.
--it would be catastrophic for many people.
I’m a lawyer. I’m legally--
No.
Listen to me, I’m legally prohibited from disclosing--
My last lawyer sold my deposition to the National Enquirer, Charlie! (beat) That happened. But the information in that deposition will be nothing compared to the consequences of those text messages--
Hang on. CHARLIE walks to his desk and picks up his copy of Molly’ Game.
Children will find out their fathers--
The movie stars you named in the book--you’d already named them under oath in the Bad Brad Marion deposition.
It was that or perjure myself and Brad had already named everyone in the game.
That’s not what I’m getting at. Your lawyer back then--Butterball--
Butterman.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 87.
Butterman leaked your deposition to the tabloids?
Yeah. CHARLIE nods that now he understands...
What.
That’s why those were the only real names you used in the book, the ones that were given up by Butterbean.
Yeah.
And is that why you have creative differences with the Hollywood offers? They want information you won’t give them?
None of this has anything to do with the Russian mob, right?
What’s on the hard drives, Molly? Famous married guys hitting on you? MOLLY nods her head “yeah”. CHARLIE picks up his cell phone and tosses it to her.
What’s this?

It’s got every e-mail and text message I’ve sent in the last year as well as a variety of incriminating evidence about my clients. If anything of yours leaks you can sell my phone to the highest bidder and I'll lose my job and be disbarred.  Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 88.
In order to demonstrate the sanctity of your attorney/client confidentiality you’re betraying the confidentiality of all your other clients?
I know you’re not gonna read it. If you're having a hard time trusting me, maybe it’ll help to know I trust you. MOLLY takes a long moment before she says--
I’ll fly home to Colorado and be back the next day with the hard drives. MOLLY tosses Charlie’s phone back to him.
Here’s how I lost the LA game.
HARLAN EUSTICE stares silently at cards we can’t see. The explodes--
Motherfucker! HARLAN’s frozen in furious silence for a moment. The othe players are quiet and don’t look at him. HARLAN grabs som food that’s on a plate and throws it at DIEGO--
Fuck you! DIEGO is professional and doesn’t react.
Fuck you, you Mexican fuck! HARLAN doesn’t get far in his tirade before MOLLY quickly steps in and defuses the situation.
You undocumented fucking border jumping fuck!

Hey HEY! (to Harlan) You get out on the terrace.
(to DIEGO) You’ve been pullin’ that shit all night!
(to HARLAN) Out on the terrace. Now. MOLLY motions to CASSIE, the relief dealer, the way a baseball manager would motion to the bullpen. MOLLY walks DIEGO away from the table--
(quietly) You good?
Yeah.
Have a drink. MOLLY goes out on to--
--where HARLAN’s waiting.
What the hell.
I’ll apologize to Diego.
Yeah and you’re gonna go home, I’m making a floor call, that’s it. HARLAN doesn’t say anything--he just stares out at Los Angeles...
(pause) Did you hear me?
I don’t have it.
Blue Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 90.
